Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Damage Control Laparotomy Versus Definitive Surgical Management in Trauma Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Trauma patients at 12 level 1 North American trauma centers were randomised

Participants.evidence: Trauma patients at 12 level 1 North American trauma centers

Intervention.evidence: damage control laparotomy (DCL) compared to definitive surgical management (DSM)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to assess the effects of damage control laparotomy (DCL) compared to definitive surgical management (DSM) on mortality and complications in trauma patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were 24-hour and 30-day mortality.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The trial included 329 patients undergoing emergent laparotomy: 213 DCL and 116 DSM.

Number_Analysed.evidence: DCL rates varied between institutions (33%-83%, p=0.002).

Result_Outcome.evidence: DCL was not associated with 30-day mortality (OR 2.33, CI 0.97-5.60).

Harms.evidence: Sepsis and ventilator-associated pneumonia occurred more frequently with DCL (p<0.05).
